;;A;;N 田园诗般的城市;在加利福尼亚州时髦的奥兰治县，你不会想到会遇到一个自称无产阶级冠军的人。亨廷顿海滩最初因石油而闻名（高中的吉祥物仍然是油人队），然后因冲浪而闻名。然而，共和党市长格雷西·范德马克(Gracey Van Der Mark)就是这样看待自己和她的城市的。她办公室的墙上挂着一份镶框的《洛杉矶时报》最近一篇专栏文章，建议（半开玩笑地）唐纳德·特朗普应该选她担任副总统。她说其他城市都害怕该州民主党州长加文·纽瑟姆，“因为他的行为就像一个暴君”。

;

;纽瑟姆先生涉嫌暴政其根源在于他的政府坚持认为城市应该建造更多的住房，而国家急需这些住房，而许多拥有富裕居民和数十座海滨平房的城市对此表示不满。在范德马克女士看来，这并不是他唯一的罪行。亨廷顿比奇在多个方面与该州作斗争，从住房法规到投票规则，再到悬挂同性恋骄傲旗帜。该市针对纽瑟姆先生的不明智的斗争象征着加州众多共和党势力与自由派州政府之间的摩擦。以及特朗普时代加州共和党的演变。

;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;

;约 41% 的亨廷顿海滩居民是注册共和党人，这使他们成为该市最大的政治部落。但最近这座城市的共和主义风格发生了变化。 2022 年，范德马克女士和几位《MAGA》同胞以候选人身份竞选市议会议员。所有人都当选了，现在与三名民主党人一起任职——尽管地方选举从技术上讲是无党派的。该委员会的民主党人朗达·博尔顿 (Rhonda Bolton) 表示，该机构的政治已经成为有毒的污泥，与美国众议院非常相似。

;

;这并不是亨廷顿海滩和政府所在地萨克拉门托的州第一次在住房问题上发生争执。 2019年，该州起诉该市涉嫌阻碍新开发项目。这次的麻烦源于该市未能批准建造住房以满足预计需求的计划，而该州每个地方政府都必须完成这一过程。州和市就此事相互起诉。该市的诉讼理由是国家不能强迫地方建设，但被驳回。该州的诉讼仍在审理中。

;

;市议会在三月份的初选上提出了几项有争议的措施，其中包括一项将引入选民- ;ID; 规则。负责投票程序的加州总检察长兼国务卿警告该市，此类措施违反了州法律。无论如何，这项措施还是通过了。另一场法律诉讼可能正在等待着。

;

;范德马克女士认为亨廷顿海滩可以制定自己的住房和投票规则，因为它是一个特许城市。加州宪法中的“地方自治”条款规定，这些采用地方宪法的城市可以“制定和执行与市政事务有关的所有法令和法规”。但该州宪法没有定义“市政事务”，由法院来决定什么是适当的。加州超过五分之一的城市拥有特许状。但亨廷顿海滩已成为地方自治的最大支持者。 “萨克拉门托将我们作为其他城市的榜样，”范德马克女士说。至少在这一点上，市政府和州政府达成了一致。

;
;
;
;;
;
;

;加州共和党人往往比东部同行更为温和。作为州长，罗纳德·里根赞成采取一些环境保护措施。阿诺·施瓦辛格环游世界，警告气候变化。然而事实证明，特朗普先生的影响力太强大，这种温和派无法持续下去。

;

;博尔顿女士表示，她认为大多数亨廷顿海滩居民比其他人更加温和委员会不会长期容忍这种欺骗行为。但选举周期对她不利。十一月选民将有机会驱逐她和其他民主党人。范德马克女士要到 2026 年才能竞选连任。该专栏暗示她是特朗普在奥兰治县的忠实士兵，这让她很高兴，但坚称除非“某个地方需要她”，否则她不会竞选更高职位。< span class="ufinish">;■;

;;C;;睫毛;一部 20 世纪 70 年代的电影《唐人街》以大萧条时期的洛杉矶为背景，供水造成致命事故。 “大旱之时，水使淹死”，一位人物惊叹道。英国最新一部水剧的受害者是企业。 4 月 5 日，英国最大的水务公司泰晤士水务公司的母公司拖欠了 14 亿英镑（17 亿美元）的债券。一场精心设计、旷日持久的重组即将到来。

;

;罪魁祸首的名单很长。首先是该公司负债累累的财务结构。其债务股本比率为78%；行业平均水平为 68%，监管机构 Ofwat 建议为 55%。这些债务分散在拜占庭式的多层公司结构中。值得注意的是，其大部分债务与通胀相关。理论上这不应该是一个问题；尽管通货膨胀率上升，但公司的主要收入来源水费也与通货膨胀相关。问题在于，债务支付与零售价格指数挂钩，自 2020 年以来，零售价格指数比与水费挂钩的通货膨胀指标 ;CPI-H; 上涨了 10%。泰晤士水务公司的部分债券定价近乎惨淡。

;
;
;
;< /div>;
;
;

;接下来，管理不善。泰晤士水务公司在 Ofwat 的效率排名中垫底。莎拉·本特利 (Sarah Bentley) 于 6 月辞去了;首席执行官;的职务，此时距八年转型计划已经实施两年了。环境罚款加剧了压力：该公用事业公司的污水溢出记录相当难看。 Ofwat 对此也负有责任：在其成立 30 年的大部分时间里，监管机构一直一心一意地控制账单。有时这是以维护和改善水基础设施为代价的。功能失调的规划系统也无济于事：英格兰最后一个主要供水水库于 1991 年竣工。

;

;泰晤士水务公司游说 Ofwat特殊待遇：削减罚款并批准大幅增加账单。以这种方式让股东摆脱困境将是一个错误。如果他们不拿出更多的钱，泰晤士水务公司应该接受特别管理，这是一种破产形式，可以让该公用事业公司保持运转，直到找到新的所有者。就像公司破产一样，股东将被消灭，债务持有人将受到沉重打击。然后，新所有者可以接管基础资产，而不会继承沉重的债务负担。

;

;进入特别管理将是做出更大改变的机会， 也。牛津大学教授迪特·赫尔姆爵士认为，泰晤士水务公司规模庞大，难以管理。他建议将供水和污水处理工作分开，并将伦敦与泰晤士河流域的其他地区分开。

;

;但是如果泰晤士河水务是一个异常值，其他水务公司也有许多问题。问题的关键在于该行业特殊的结构。供水是典型的自然垄断。由于公用事业之间不可能竞争，政府对私有化的自来水公司实行严格的监管。 Ofwat 设定公司可以收取的账单，确定他们可以进行哪些投资并选择回报率。

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;这些决定每五年做出一次。下一次审查涵盖 2025 年至 2029 年底，预计将于 12 月结束。过去的迭代一直存在争议。 2019年，Ofwat否决了该行业提出的30%的资产改善投资，称这些计划缺乏明确的理由，而且物有所值。现在 Ofwat 表示，其想法已经转变，希望在投资方面做出重大改变。这意味着相应增加水费来为其提供资金，尽管实际涨幅低于公司开盘价的 31%（见图表）。

;

;欢迎改变语气。但 Ofwat 是否会发生足够的变化仍是一个悬而未决的问题。一个风向标是允许的回报率，这对于吸引急需的外国资本至关重要。 Ofwat 预计通胀率为 3.29%（以;CPIH;衡量）。考虑到该行业风险不断上升以及整个经济体无风险利率上升，这一数字几乎肯定太低了。经历了过去几年的困难，投资者不会被中等回报引诱入水。

;

;“唐人街”以扩张告终洛杉矶的供水（以及暴力）。考虑到人口增长和气候变化的压力，英国老旧的供水基础设施也需要升级。这需要更多的投资。泰晤士水务传奇的正确结局将给当前股东和未来的账单支付者带来痛苦。 ;■;

;
; /div>;
;
;

;政府如何处理外国大使馆的规范延伸了几个世纪。古希腊和罗马政府对外国特使及其任务提供了保护。 1961年，《维也纳外交关系公约》中规定了规则。第22条规定，外交前提是不可侵犯的。未经大使或宣教负责人的同意，当地警察或安全部队不得进入大使馆。东道国有义务保护房屋。根据东道国的法律，在那里工作的人免于起诉。一些政府抱怨说，这允许使馆掩盖肮脏的人物。但是规则很重要：它们允许外交官在不担心被骚扰或劫持人质的情况下工作，并可以帮助保持有态度关系的国家之间的稳定性。

;

;违反不可侵犯的后果可能很严重。美国国务院认为对其一个使馆的袭击是对美国本身的攻击。实际上，大使馆的特殊地位偶尔才经过认真的测试。 1979年，在伊朗新的革命伊斯兰政府的支持下，学生活动家扩大了美国大使馆在德黑兰的墙壁，并在444天持有50多名美国外交官。国际法院（; ICJ ;）迅速裁定针对伊朗。两国之间的关系从未恢复过，伊朗仍然是国际贱民。

;

;一些政府试图破坏滥用不可侵犯性。 1984 年，一名警察伊冯·弗莱彻 (Yvonne Fletcher) 在伦敦广场被利比亚大使馆内的枪手杀害，此后，英国通过了一项法律，取消了对被滥用的外交馆舍的保护。迄今为止，该法律只使用过一次，清除了侵占长期空置的柬埔寨大使馆的擅自占地者。 Wikileaks的创始人朱利安·阿桑奇（Julian Assange）在伦敦驻厄瓜多尔大使馆寻求庇护，以避免因性侵犯指控避免引渡瑞典。 （这些指控后来被撤销，但阿桑奇先生在厄瓜多尔于2019年撤销了庇护后被英国警察逮捕，并且是;战斗引渡;到美国，他在那里被控黑客攻击政府计算机。）

;
;
;

;; T;;HE INDIA; I grew up in had just secured its independence and was struggling to meet essential needs like food, fuel and foreign exchange. It is now the world's second-largest food producer, measured by calorie content, and a net food exporter. India still imports fuel but is increasingly harnessing solar and wind power. Foreign-exchange reserves are at an all-time high. India is now the world's fifth-largest economy and some analysts predict it could be the third-largest by 2027.

;

;In the past, during negotiations with the multilateral organisations and investors, India would often be described as a country of great potential that would remain one. For many years the gibe may not have been entirely unfair: India progressed in fits and starts.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The balance-of-payments crisis in 1991-93 was an important course correction for macroeconomic stability and structural reforms. Further big changes occurred under the leadership of Atal Bihari Vajpayee in 1996 and 1998-2004: telecommunications and road networks were expanded, boosting productivity, integrating underdeveloped regions with more advanced ones and stimulating competition in Indian manufacturing. The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (;FRBM;) Act of 2003 marked another turning point, underlining the importance of economic stability for private investment. But then reforms slowed from 2004 to 2014.

;

;During the past ten years, however, India has decisively disproved the “country of potential” quip 。 The IMF describes the country as an economic “bright spot”. Research by the State Bank of India finds a steady decline in the incremental capital-output ratio—a measure of the relationship between investment and increase in ;GDP;—to 4.4 in the latest April-to-March financial year, compared to 7.5 a decade before. This suggests that part of India's growth stems from producing more with less.

;

;India has set itself the target of becoming a developed economy by 2047, the year that marks the centenary of its independence. What issues does it need to focus on to get there?

;

;The first is poverty. Eliminating it must be the raison d'être of any meaningful economic strategy for a densely populated country of 1.4bn people. If you accept India's official definition of poverty—just under $2 of income a day—then rural poverty is estimated at 2.5% and urban poverty at 1%. These estimates do not take into account free food and other direct-transfer benefits from various government programmes. Still, India should aim higher. Poverty must be brought down, and this should be done while raising the official definition from the current level to at least $3 of daily income, ideally $3.50.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The second task is to maintain macroeconomic stability by implementing the ;FRBM; act. Under this law, the fiscal deficit was to be reduced to 3% of ;GDP; for both central and state governments, and the debt-to-;GDP; ratio was to be reduced to 60%。 Twenty years later this still has not happened.

;

;The increased public spending needed to handle the covid-19 pandemic made those goals even more elusive. Since the pandemic, however, the situation has improved: the budget estimate of the likely fiscal deficit for the 2023-24 financial year indicates a narrowing, to 5.8% of ;GDP;, and the government hopes to reduce it to 4.5% in 2025-26. Public debt appears to be falling, too—towards 80% of ;GDP; compared to almost 90% in 2020-21. Alongside this, productivity will rise if the government continues to shift more of its spending into asset-creating capital projects.

;

;The third big issue is tackling climate change. India is playing its part enthusiastically through its “nationally determined contributions” under the Paris agreement of 2015. It is also a leader in sectoral initiatives, for instance the International Solar Alliance, an inter-governmental organisation comprising 118 countries. It has started to restructure agriculture towards less fossil-fuel-dependent production, by for instance moving to less energy-intensive cereals like millets. And it is ploughing money into green hydrogen.

;

;But India still has far to go to significantly reduce its dependence on fossil fuels. An orderly transition requires, among other things, enhancing the efficiency of state-owned distribution companies, phasing out inefficient fossil-fuel power plants and accelerating the shift towards a renewables-powered grid. Change at the national level will not be enough. It will also require international action, not least further reform of multilateral development banks, based on the recommendations of the ;G20;'s Independent Expert Group.

;

;The fourth area of concern is skills development. India's declining dependency ratio—the share of the population that is young or elderly—makes it all the more important to improve skills and roll out new technology, including, for instance, to provide better online courses. The government's new National Education Policy is putting the country on the right track. It may also help to bring much of the grey economy into the formal sector.

;

;India must develop a new model of growth, relying on technology instead of on more incremental and material-intensive manufacturing and export-led growth. India will never be a manufacturing-export powerhouse. Its best hope for future growth lies in focusing on capital expenditure and in further developing its service sectors.

;

;Geopolitical risks that make energy more expensive or interrupt critical supply chains will pose challenges. But they will not derail India. The country's recent stint chairing the ;G20,; and the resulting New Delhi Leaders' Declaration, showed how relations with America and Russia can be balanced, allowing India to, for instance, continue to import oil at affordable prices. As a large, growing market with much unsaturated demand, India is well placed to turn geopolitical uncertainties to its advantage.

;

;India's leaders have good reasons to want to achieve the four big goals. They understand that political stability is contingent on strong economic growth and on the efficient delivery of public goods through technology-enabled public distribution systems and various kinds of subsidy payments. This may, finally, be India's moment. ;■;

;;I;;n “Permutation City”;, a novel by Greg Egan, the character Peer, having achieved immortality within a virtual reality over which he has total control, finds himself terribly bored.因此，他让自己拥有了新的激情。某一时刻，他正在突破高等数学的界限；另一时刻，他正在突破高等数学的界限。接下来他正在写歌剧。 “He'd even been interested in the Elysians [the afterlife], once.不再。他更喜欢考虑桌腿。” Peer's fickleness relates to a deeper point. When technology has solved humanity's deepest problems, what is left to do?

;

;That is one question considered in a new book by Nick Bostrom, a philosopher at the University of Oxford, whose ;last book; argued that humanity faced a one-in-six chance of being wiped out in the next 100 years, perhaps owing to the development of dangerous forms of artificial intelligence (;AI;). In Mr Bostrom's latest publication, “Deep Utopia”, he considers a rather different outcome. What happens if ;AI ;goes extraordinarily well? Under one scenario presented in the book, the technology progresses to the point at which it can do all economically valuable work at near-zero cost. Under a yet more radical scenario, even tasks that you might think would be reserved for humans, such as parenting, can be done better by ;AI;.; ;This may sound more dystopian than utopian, but Mr Bostrom argues otherwise.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Start with the first scenario, which Mr Bostrom labels a “post-scarcity” Utopia. In such a world, the need for work would be reduced. Almost a century ago John Maynard Keynes wrote an essay entitled “Economic Possibilities for Our Grandchildren”, which predicted that 100 years into the future his wealthy descendants would need to work for only 15 hours a week. This has not quite come to pass, but working time has fallen greatly. In the rich world average weekly working hours have dropped from more than 60 in the late 19th century to fewer than 40 today. The typical American spends a third of their waking hours on leisure activities and sports. In the future, they may wish to spend their time on things beyond humanity's current conception. As Mr Bostrom writes, when aided by powerful tech, “the space of possible-for-us experiences extends far beyond those that are accessible to us with our present unoptimised brains.”

;

;Yet Mr Bostrom's label of a “post-scarcity” Utopia might be slightly misleading: the economic explosion caused by superintelligence would still be limited by physical resources, most notably land.尽管太空探索可能会极大地增加可用的建筑空间，但它不会使其变得无限。也有一些中间世界，人类在那里发展出强大的新智能形式，但并没有成为太空旅行者。 In such worlds, wealth may be fantastic, but lots of it could be absorbed by housing—much as is the case in rich countries today.

;

;“Positional goods”, which boost the status of their owners, are also still likely to exist and are, by their nature, scarce. Even if ;AI;s surpass humans in art, intellect, music and sport, humans will probably continue to derive value from surpassing their fellow humans; for example, by having tickets to the hottest events. In 1977 Fred Hirsch, an economist, argued in “The Social Limits to Growth” that, as wealth increases, a greater fraction of human desire consists of positional goods. Time spent competing goes up, the price of such goods increases and so their share of ;GDP ;rises. This pattern may continue in an ;AI; Utopia.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;Mr Bostrom notes some types of competition are a failure of co-ordination: if everyone agrees to stop competing, they would have time for other, better things, which could further boost growth. Yet some types of competition, such as sport, have intrinsic value, and are worth preserving. (Humans may also have nothing better to do.) Interest in chess has grown since ;IBM;'s Deep Blue first defeated Garry Kasparov, then world champion, in 1997. An entire industry has emerged around e-sports, where computers can comfortably defeat humans; their revenues are expected to grow at a 20% annual rate over the next decade, reaching nearly $11bn by 2032. Several groups in society today give us a sense of how future humans might spend their time. Aristocrats and bohemians enjoy the arts. Monastics live within themselves. Athletes spend their lives on sport. The retired dabble in all these pursuits.

;;

;Everyone's early retirement

;

;Won't tasks such as parenting remain the refuge of humans? Mr Bostrom is not so sure. He argues that beyond the post-scarcity world lies a “post-instrumental” one, in which ;AI;s would become superhuman at child care, too. Keynes himself wrote that “there is no country and no people, I think, who can look forward to the age of leisure and of abundance without a dread. For we have been trained too long to strive and not to enjoy…To judge from the behaviour and the achievements of the wealthy classes today in any quarter of the world, the outlook is very depressing!” The Bible puts it more succinctly: “idle hands are the devil's workshop.”

;

;These dynamics suggest a “paradox of progress”.尽管大多数人都想要一个更美好的世界，但如果技术变得太先进，他们可能会失去目标。博斯特罗姆先生认为，大多数人仍然会喜欢具有内在价值的活动，例如吃美味的食物。乌托邦主义者认为生活变得太容易了，他们可能会决定挑战自己，也许通过殖民一个新星球来尝试从头开始重新设计文明。然而，到了某个时候，即使是这样的冒险也可能不再值得。正如皮尔在《排列城市》中所做的那样，人类会在激情之间快乐地跳跃多久，这是一个悬而未决的问题。长期以来，经济学家一直认为人类拥有“无限的需求和欲望”，这表明人们想要消费的东西有无穷无尽的变化。 With the arrival of an ;AI; Utopia, this would be put to the test.很大程度上取决于结果。 ;■;

;;F;;OR ALMOST; as long as it has been accepted in China that “to get rich is glorious” , it has also been known that to ; get out can be glorious;, too. The urge felt by many newly well-off Chinese citizens to emigrate has been a big reason for the growth of “investment migration” businesses. According to the Investment Migration Council, a lobby for the industry, more than 80 countries offer schemes in which fast-track residence rights (“golden visas”), or even citizenship (“golden passports”), are available to foreigners who invest large sums. The most popular has been America's, where the waiting-list for Chinese applicants reached 15 years in 2022. For tiny countries such as Vanuatu and St Kitts and Nevis citizenship-by-investment schemes are important sources of foreign exchange.

;

;China is the biggest source of demand, but far from the only one.世界各地的人们都想移居其他国家——逃离迫害、政治不稳定，或者在某些情况下逃离正义。许多人只是希望让孩子接受更好的教育，或者在气候宜人、美食丰富的地方工作。他们给东道国带来的资金似乎使这种安排实现了双赢。 Yet, as the closure in recent years of a number of schemes demonstrates, they are highly controversial.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;In every country the question of who has the right to live there is a sensitive one. But for the European Union (;EU;) in particular golden visas raise fundamental issues. They touch on one of the most “national” of competences—who lives in a country—yet, because of the Schengen arrangements, allowing free movement across most of the bloc, have union-wide consequences. There has been a prolonged tussle between Brussels and the countries offering visas and passports in return for investment.

;

;The European Commission and the ;OECD;, a rich-country think-tank, have long worried that golden visas provide cover for money-laundering. Those fears are not without foundation. In Greece, for example, Chinese investors were in 2018 accused of complicity in a scam in which a Greek developer bought properties at market value and sold them at a big mark-up to would-be investment migrants in China, then partially reimbursed them.

;

;In 2022 the European Parliament called for an outright ban on golden passports and the imposition of strict rules on golden visas.在护照方面，布鲁塞尔似乎获胜。 Malta is now the only ;EU ;country still to offer citizenship by investment.在签证方面，事情也变得越来越困难。 In 2023 Greece doubled the minimum investment under its scheme to €500,000 ($543,000) in some of the more popular parts of the country, though opposition parties still claim it is the world's most popular and want it closed.

;

;On April 8th Spain revealed plans to ditch its programme, which offered non-;EU; citizens who invested more than 500,000 euros ($541,250) the right to live and work there on a renewable permit that made them eligible for permanent residency after ten years.该计划的最大用户是中国和俄罗斯公民。其90%以上的投资都投向了房地产。 It is the scheme's alleged effect on the property market—pushing the cost of buying or renting property out of the reach of many locals—that has prompted Spain's government to seek to drop it.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;That is a relatively common concern.出于类似原因，爱尔兰于 2023 年 2 月关闭了类似计划。当月，葡萄牙宣布终止其黄金签证计划，这是旨在解决住房危机的一揽子措施的一部分。 A revised scheme came into effect in October: investment in property or property funds no longer qualifies.

;

;The concern about golden visas is not confined to欧洲。一月份，澳大利亚取消了向投资至少 500 万澳元（330 万美元）的外国人提供永久居留权的计划。自2012年推出该签证以来，已签发了数千份签证，其中大部分发给了中国公民。但该计划因助长腐败而受到批评。 Similar fears in Britain—;focused on Russian; rather than Chinese criminality—led to its ditching its “Tier-1” visa for wealthy foreigners in 2022 just before the invasion of Ukraine.

;

;The investment-migration market is getting tighter, as governments find ever more reasons to question whether its economic benefits outweigh its political and other costs. Money can still buy you a visa, and even a passport in some places. But the world's footloose rich are finding it can't buy you love.;■;

;;我;;N;乌克兰对安东诺夫斯基大桥发动火箭袭击的准备阶段，安东诺夫斯基大桥是通往被占领地区的重要道路在第聂伯河东岸的赫尔松市，安全官员仔细研究了一系列特别报告。那是 2022 年夏天，俄罗斯严重依赖这座桥为其第聂伯河以西的部队提供补给。这些报告包含对两件事的研究：摧毁这座桥是否会导致俄罗斯士兵或其家人感到恐慌？更重要的是，乌克兰政府如何通过创造“特定的信息环境”来最大限度地打击士气？

;

;Sviatoslav Hnizdovsky 就是这样的基辅开放思想研究所 (;OMI;) 的创始人介绍了他的研究机构通过人工智能 (;AI;) 生成这些评估所做的工作。 Algorithms sifted through oceans of Russian social-media content and socioeconomic data on things ranging from alcohol consumption and population movements to online searches and consumer behaviour. ;AI; 将任何变化与俄罗斯“忠诚主义者”和自由主义者对其国家士兵潜在困境的不断变化的情绪联系起来。

;

;赫尼兹多夫斯基先生表示，这项高度敏感的工作将继续影响乌克兰关于战争进程的重要决策。这包括未来可能对俄罗斯;刻赤大桥;，这是俄罗斯和克里米亚之间唯一的直接陆地连接。

;配备 ChatGPT

;

;乌克兰在军事上落后于俄罗斯，越来越多地寻求利用;人工智能;优势，作者：;以多种方式利用技术;。一名参与武器开发的乌克兰上校表示，无人机设计者通常将 Chat;GPT; 视为工程理念的“起点”，例如减少俄罗斯干扰脆弱性的新技术。这位要求匿名的上校表示，;人工智能;的另一个军事用途是识别目标。

;

;作为士兵而且军事博主明智地对自己的帖子变得更加谨慎，简单地搜索有关部队位置的任何线索已经变得不那么有效。然而，通过摄取大量图像和文本，<小>;人工智能;模型可以找到潜在的线索，将它们拼接在一起，然后推测武器系统或部队编队的可能位置。 Molfar 是一家在第聂伯罗和基辅设有办事处的情报公司，该公司分析师 Maksym Zrazhevsky 表示，将这种“拼图”方法与;AI;结合使用，通常每天都能找到两到五个有价值的目标。一旦被发现，这些情报就会迅速传递给乌克兰军队，导致一些目标被摧毁。

;;AI 协助定位; 以其他方式。 SemanticForce 是一家立陶宛公司，在基辅和乌克兰西部城市捷尔诺波尔设有办事处，该公司开发的模型可以响应文本提示，审查在线或上传的文本和图像。 SemanticForce 的许多客户在商业上使用该系统来监控公众对其品牌的看法。然而，莫尔法使用该模型来绘制俄罗斯军队可能士气低落和补给不足的地区，这可能使他们成为较软的目标。 ;AI; 在图片中寻找线索，包括无人机镜头以及社交媒体中士兵的怒吼。

;

;它还使用偷偷摸摸的代理索引了有关俄罗斯军事弱点的线索。为此，Molfar 使用 SemanticForce 的 ;AI; 生成有关俄罗斯志愿者团体活动的报告，这些志愿者团体为前线最需要的部门筹集资金并准备护理包。 Molfar说，算法在丢弃潜在误导的机器人帖子方面做得很好。 （带有刺耳的政治触发器的帐户是一个提示。）公司的分析师有时通过使用掩盖电话来源的软件来增强这种情报。该公司 45 多名分析师中，有 10 名负责目标定位工作，并且免费为乌克兰军队提供服务。

;

;然后是反情报工作。 ;人工智能;的使用帮助乌克兰间谍抓捕者识别出直到最近担任国家安全与国防委员会(;NSDC;)秘书的奥列克西·丹尼洛夫(Oleksiy Danilov)所说的“容易背叛”的人。乌克兰前信息政策副部长德米特罗·佐洛图欣 (Dmytro Zolotukhin) 表示，通过拍摄基础设施和军事资产的地理定位照片赚钱的提议经常发送到乌克兰手机。他本人最近收到了一封这样的短信。他补充道，尝试这个“情报服务市场”的人经常会被乌克兰的 ;SBU; 情报机构逮捕。

;使用 <乌克兰反情报机构利用美国公司 Palantir 的人工智能技术，寻找不同数据池中的联系。例如，想象一下，一名负债累累的离婚者，面临着失去公寓和孩子监护权的风险，他开设了一个外国银行账户，并在后来被导弹袭击的地点附近被发现携带手机。除了这种点连接之外，;AI;还执行“社交网络分析”。比如说，如果假设的离婚者与俄罗斯有很强的个人联系，并且已经开始接听某人的电话，而该人的手机使用情况表明其社会地位较高，那么;人工智能;可能会增加他的风险评分。

;< p data-component="paragraph" class="css-121tnhw e1tt35bk0">;十多年来，;AI; 对网络节点之间交互的评估结果令人印象深刻。 2013 年为阿富汗内政部提供咨询的前英国情报官员克里斯蒂安·古斯塔夫森 (Kristian Gustafson) 讲述了一名为塔利班权贵运送大量现金的快递员被抓获的经历。他说，他们随后的电话“点亮了整个图”。从那时起，计算“中介中心性”（影响力的衡量标准）等算法的进步，正如另一位前情报官员所说，让那些日子看起来“相当原始”。

;

; ;AI ;的使用已经发展了一段时间。乌克兰总统弗拉基米尔·泽伦斯基 (Volodymyr Zelensky) 于 2019 年 11 月呼吁大力推动该技术在国家安全中的应用。结果是由 ;NSDC; 构建和运行的具有战略意义的模型，该模型可以摄取文本、统计数据、照片和视频。 ;NSDC; 的参谋长安德烈·齐乌兹 (Andriy Ziuz) 表示，该中心被称为威胁评估运营中心 (;COTA;)，提供广泛的信息，其中一些信息是黑客获取的。该模型跟踪价格、电话使用、移民、贸易、能源、政治、外交和军事发展，直至修理店的武器。

;

; ;COTA ;的运营商将此模型称为“构造函数”。这是因为它还吸收较小模型的输出，例如 Palantir 的软件和 Delta，后者是支持乌克兰军队机动决策的战场软件。 ;NSDC; 的首席技术专家 Mykola Dobysh 表示，;COTA; 的“大局”输出为高级官员提供了敏感问题上的指导，包括动员政策。丹尼洛夫先生指出，泽伦斯基先生已在 130 多次场合听取过关于 ;COTA; 评估的简报，其中一次是在俄罗斯全面入侵当天的上午 10 点。 ;COTA; 的部分（或“电路”）的访问权限提供给其他一些团体，包括保险公司、外交部和美国能源部。

;

;乌克兰的;人工智能;努力受益于其社会为战争贡献数据的广泛意愿。公民将可能与国家国防相关的带有地理标记的照片上传到名为 Diia（乌克兰语“行动”）的政府应用程序中。许多企业向位于利沃夫的 Mantis Analytics 公司提供运营数据，包括延迟交货、呼叫中心活动以及防盗警报的触发等。该平台社会功能评估的接收者包括国防部和寻求以更好的方式部署自身安全资源的公司。

;;R;;美国的入侵;已将乌克兰变成世界上地雷最严重的国家。在赫尔松和哈尔科夫，俄罗斯士兵撤退时留下了雷区。他们不仅埋设地雷来保卫自己的阵地，还利用地雷扰乱乌克兰的农业生产。俄罗斯的一种火箭系统（称为“zemledeliye”或“农业”）可将地雷投掷到距离发射器 15 公里的地方。农业是乌克兰经济的支柱：2021年农产品出口价值277亿美元，占出口总额的40%以上。但据 ;NASA; 称，自 2022 年 2 月以来，乌克兰 7.5% 的农田目前尚未使用。国防部地雷行动局统计负责人叶夫海尼·祖巴列夫斯基上校表示，人员伤亡也造成了影响：170名农民被杀，几乎占因地雷或未爆弹药造成的平民死亡的20%。随着春播的到来，正在做什么？

;当俄罗斯入侵开始时，只有四家机构被授权在乌克兰开展排雷行动，除了军队和政府机构。如今，这个数字已达到 29 个，还有 19 个正在获取必要的许可证。但排雷人员仍然不知所措。适当的清理工作既困难又昂贵：团队首先会采访当地人并寻找线索，例如可能表明存在地雷或未爆炸炮弹的弹坑，然后再携带探测设备和防护装备进入。 Nibulon 是乌克兰一家大型谷物出口商，拥有自己的排雷部门，只向农民收取费用。即便如此，每公顷排雷的成本也超过 5,000 美元。尽管有政府补贴，但这对许多农民来说成本太高。尼布隆政府关系主管米哈伊洛·里扎克 (Mykhailo Rizak) 表示，有些人购买或租用了远离前线的土地。他感叹道，其他人已经把事情掌握在自己手中了。

;;DIY ;排雷在小型农场最为常见。前农业部副部长、现任乌克兰农民和私人土地所有者协会成员维克托·谢雷梅塔 (Viktor Sheremeta) 估计，他的 10,000 名会员中约有十分之一已经做到了这一点。在用金属探测器或长刺发现地雷后，大多数人都会向当局发出警报。但有些人会自行引爆地雷——通过在拖拉机前部投掷物体或使用滚筒来引爆地雷。废钢装甲。这当然是非常危险的。

;

;排雷黑市也随之兴起。这些“黑暗排雷者”通过低工资雇用工人并且不为他们提供保险来提供低廉的工资。尽管许多此类排雷人员都是前战斗工程师，但他们往往缺乏处理最新地雷的经验。赫尔松地区的农民奥莱·乌什卡洛 (Oleh Ushkalo) 遇到无证排雷人员，提出以每公顷 100 美元左右的便宜价格清理他的土地。他拒绝了。俄罗斯士兵偷了他的联合收割机，他错过了收成，导致他缺乏现金。他也不信任承包商。他发现的一些地雷是用塑料包裹的，因此很难被发现。乌什卡洛先生说，邻近农场的反坦克地雷导致七名拖拉机司机死亡。

;

;通常，俄罗斯军队驻扎的地方会雇佣黑暗排雷员很快就穿过了，没有留下密集的雷区。 They are also more common within 20km of the front, where non-governmental deminers are not allowed.里扎克先生说，大多数人都是由不向税务员报告收成并希望避开政府监视的农场雇用的。他补充道，农业领域的逃税现象已十分普遍。

;

;黑暗排雷人员的工作质量低劣，非常危险，使他们及其客户面临风险。糟糕的程序实际上可能会将地雷推到使检测和清除变得更加困难的位置。乌克兰安全官员表示，被地雷杀死的农民中大约有一半是在进行过简易排雷的田地里进行的。

;

;现在大多数田地去年冬天解冻后，临时清理无疑正在兴起。但总部位于基辅的慈善机构“炸弹技术无国界”的托尼·萨尔沃看到了一个令人鼓舞的迹象。由于伤亡不断增加，乌克兰警方已经认识到黑暗排雷的危险。过去，警察通常只在事故发生后才做出反应，现在他们正在主动调查黑暗排雷者。打击行动已经开始。;■;

;;U;;NTIL RECENTLY; Captain James Cook was not a particularly controversial figure.但今年 1 月，墨尔本一座 18 世纪英国水手兼探险家的雕像被推倒，底座上喷上了“殖民地将陷落”的字样。 In Hawaii an obelisk in Cook's memory has been splattered with red paint and the message “You are on native land.” Cook has joined Edward Colston, Robert Clive and Cecil Rhodes as a focal point for anti-colonialist ire.

;

;In fact Cook was neither a slave trader nor much of an imperialist.首先，他是一位出色的航海家和制图师。根据海军部的命令，他于 1768 年至 1779 年间在太平洋进行了三次开创性航行。他的地图制作改变了欧洲人对世界上最大海洋的认识。

;
;
;
;
;

;An excellent new book draws on Cook's letters and notebooks to tell the story of his third and final trip. 1776 年 7 月，库克登上;;皇家海军;决心号;出发时已年近 50 岁。他所带的船员中有 William Bligh（后来的;Bounty 号;船长） 1789 年叛变之前）和大溪地王子麦（Mai），因约书亚·雷诺兹爵士（Sir Joshua Reynolds）的画而闻名。 Cook had secret instructions from the Admiralty not only to claim new territory for Britain, but to search for a north-west passage via the Bering Strait (a task even someone with his navigational experience found impossible).

;

;The author, Hampton Sides, focuses on Cook's return to Australia and New Zealand—countries the explorer had first encountered almost a decade earlier—his discovery of the Society Islands (today part of French Polynesia) and his time in Hawaii. It was there, in February 1779, that he was killed after a botched attempt to kidnap a local chief in response to the theft of a longboat.

;

;Cook was a man of his times.他相信欧洲将对太平洋地区许多愚昧的人民产生文明的影响。 He was distinctly cruel in meting out punishments, to his own crew as well as to any indigenous people who opposed him.

;

;Yet Cook also admired many of the people and places he encountered in the South Pacific.与西班牙人不同，他对宗教皈依不感兴趣。 He tried hard to stop his men from spreading venereal disease. For the most part, his land claims were aimed not at promoting a British empire but forestalling grabs by Britain's rivals, France and Spain.

;;M;;ORE THAN; two decades have passed since we published an academic paper linking the legalisation of abortion to the enormous decline in American crime since the 1990s. The underlying theory is straightforward. Children who are unwanted at birth are at risk of a range of adverse life outcomes and commit much more crime later in life. Legalised abortion greatly reduced the number of unwanted births. Consequently, legalised abortion will reduce crime, albeit with substantial lags.

;

;Our paper created much controversy, which was further stoked by a chapter on the topic in the best-selling book “Freakonomics”, written by one of us with Stephen Dubner, published in 2005. For many, it was more important to spin a political response to our hypothesis than to evaluate whether it was correct.

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;The data available at the time strongly supported our hypothesis. We showed, for instance, that crime began falling sooner in the five states that legalised abortion in advance of ;Roe v Wade;, the US Supreme Court decision that made abortion available legally nationwide. We documented that crime in states with high and low abortion rates followed nearly identical trends for many years, then suddenly and persistently diverged only after the birth cohorts exposed to legal abortion reached the age at which they would commit crime. Consistent with our theory, looking at arrest data, which reveal the age of the offender, the declines in crime were concentrated among those born after abortion became legal.

;

;These data patterns do not, of course, make an open-and-shut case. No randomised experiment has been conducted on this topic. We also didn't help our own case by mislabelling the set of control variables included in one of the specifications in one of our tables—a regrettable mistake (later corrected) which led some people to dismiss all of the paper's findings. One of the most vocal and consistently sceptical voices arguing against our findings has been ;The Economist;, which has written about our study on three occasions (most recently ;last month;), each time taking a critical and dismissive stance.

;

;We concede that reasonable people could disagree about how convincing the findings were in our initial paper. The analysis was retrospective, and there is always the concern that researchers have cherry-picked their findings, or that perhaps it was just pure coincidence that the patterns emerged.

;

;There is, however, something unique about our hypothesis, which allows a second test of the theory that is far closer to the ideal of the scientific method. There is a long lag between abortions being performed and the affected cohort reaching the age at which crime is committed. Thus, we could already at the time of our first academic paper in 2001 make strong predictions about what our theory would predict should happen to future crime. Indeed, at the end of that paper, we made the following prediction: “When a steady state is reached roughly 20 years from now, the impact of abortion will be roughly twice as great as the impact felt so far. Our results suggest that all else equal, legalised abortion will account for persistent declines of 1% a year in crime over the next two decades.”

;
;
;
;
;
;
;

;It is rare—almost unprecedented—in academic economics to be able to make a testable prediction and then to go back and actually test it decades later. That's what we did in a ;paper; published in 2020. Our methodological approach was straightforward: mimic the specifications reported in our original paper, but limit the time period to the years that were out of sample, ie, those after our original data ended.

;

;The results provided stunning corroboration of our predictions. For each of the seven different analyses we had presented in the initial 2001 paper, the results for next two decades of data were at least as strong as the results in our initial dataset, and in most specifications even stronger. This included what the main critics of our 2001 paper called the “crucial” test, showing that the abortion rate at the time of any birth cohort negatively correlated with the age-specific arrest rate for that cohort years later as it moved through ages 15–24, while perfectly controlling for whatever other factors were influencing crime in a given state and a given year. We would argue that, short of a randomised experiment, this is some of the most compelling evidence one could present.

;

;The magnitude of the implied impacts we are talking about is huge. If you look over the entire sample, violent-crime rates fell by 62.2 percentage points in high-abortion states whereas they rose by 3.1% in low-abortion states.

;

;Though there is not complete acceptance of our hypothesis among academics, all agree that if our paper is not correct, then there is no viable explanation for the enormous drop in crime in America that started in the early 1990s. Indeed, there is not even an arguable theory to supplant the abortion-crime link. Exposure to lead in the environment might, perhaps, be the next best hypothesis. But as we showed in our 2020 paper, when one controls for both environmental lead and abortion, the coefficient on abortion remains large while the coefficient on environmental lead is greatly reduced and loses statistical significance.

;

;It seems fair to ask why, in spite of strong supporting evidence, no academic contradiction of any of the findings of our 2020 paper and support for the abortion-crime link from ;international evidence;, so many observers remain sceptical of the hypothesis. Not surprisingly, those whose livelihoods came from fighting crime during the great crime drop were not keen to conclude that their approaches—whether more police, more incarceration or particular social programmes—however important they might have been, were not the dominant factor in the decline 。 Another possible explanation is that people across the political spectrum were uncomfortable with our conclusions. Many people would prefer that our hypothesis not be true—perhaps not recognising that the core finding is that when women can control their fertility the life outcomes of their children are greatly enhanced.

;

;History is full of instances where new scientific theories were resisted by those who found them inconvenient. By and large, history hasn't been kind to the resisters.;■;
